As a Wharton undergraduate, you are in a position to become a future business leader. Management 100 is designed to increase your understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help you build skills that are necessary for professional success. You will study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of the course. Your field project provides the context in which you will develop as a leader, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance your sensitivity to community issues. Management 100 will enrich your Wharton experience by providing many opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community. Management 100 provides occasions to strengthen your ability to exercise leadership through service, to speak and write persuasively, and to work collaboratively with a diverse group of individuals. By the end of the term, you will forge relationships with members of your team and section and also have a greater sense of your individual strengths and opportunities for personal development. Over the course of the year, Wharton undergraduates complete nearly 70 field projects through Management 100. In the fall, freshmen participate in community service projects, a good number supplied by the United Way; in the spring, upper level transfer and dual degree students work on consulting projects sponsored by Wharton’s Small Business Development Center (SBDC). The field projects—whether community service or consulting—provide an excellent opportunity for you to develop your skills, participate in a high performance team, and contribute to the greater community. 
This course is a requirement for all Wharton students.

Students found this course to be “very informative”. Some found the course to be “fun and interesting”, as well as “an enjoyable challenge”. Students valued the team bonding that ensued, but some wished there had been more communication with all students in the lecture, rather than just teams. Overall, students felt that MGMT 100 fostered leadership skills and the ability to work within a group. While commenting that the amount of work and course-load was burdensome and often quite excessive, students felt that in the end “it was all valuable and sparks an interest in management.” Students found the course to provide knowledge that would be practical in the business world. 

Students were overall impressed with Professor Greenhalgh’s ability to communicate the subject matter and accessibility outside of the classroom and willingness to help. Students praised Professor Greenhalgh as a “perfect,” “incredible,” and “terrific” instructor. One student commented that he was “thrilled and honored to have had the pleasure of learning from her.” Students felt that Professor Greenhalgh stimulated student interest and “facilitates student participation” in an engaging manner. 

Students felt that, though this course was a lot of work, the more effort they put in the more knowledge and skill they learned. Students found the in-class presentations to be stressful, and the preparation to be time consuming, but felt that they gained tremendously from the process. Some students criticized the status reports as not being useful, and one student commented that some of the projects “take a lot of time and are not related to the course.” Students felt that by the end of the course, the material had become somewhat “repetitive” and “meaningless”. Some students did not like working in groups and thus being graded as a group.

Management 100 is designed to increase students’ understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help them to build skills that are necessary for professional success. Students study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project. The field project provides the context in which students develop as leaders, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance their sensitivity to community issues. Management 100 is intended to enrich the Wharton experience by providing many opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community.

Opinions about Management 100 were mixed. Many students felt that they “gained a great deal of real world experience” and learned a lot about themselves and “how to work in teams.” A number commented that they “enjoyed working with [their] group[s]” and that “the team interaction was the most useful portion” of the course. A couple described the readings as “relevant and interesting.” On the other hand, a large contingent of students felt that the course “involved a lot of fluffy subject matter,” “suffered from a general lack of substance and concrete intellectual structure,” and was “full of busy work.”

Students had mostly positive opinions of Professor Maxwell, describing him as “amazing,” “very professional,” and “highly competent.” One student said “he genuinely cared and showed interest in MGMT” and another said that he made “the course fun and also educational.” However, students found his interaction with students to be weak. One said that “he was very distanced from students” and another described him as “a little dry. ” A couple of students praised the team advisors.

Students agreed that the class was “a lot of work” and took “up a lot of time, between the extra hours put in for the project and the presentations.” Many students also objected to the grading system, which they described as “too subjective” and which a few students said created a “cutthroat atmosphere.” Additionally, several students felt that “the people who deserved A's [wouldn’t] necessarily get them.” Others complained, “the lack of transparency in grading left students without any idea how or whether they should change their approaches until the very end of the semester.” All first-year Wharton students are required to take Management 100. Freshmen generally take Management 100 during their first semester while transfer and dual-degree students typically take it in the spring of their first year at Wharton.

MGMT 100 is designed to increase one’s understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help build skills that are necessary for professional success. The course involves study of literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also includes a field project. The field project provides the context in which the student develops as a leader, practices communication skills, learns about the nature of group work, and enhances his or her sensitivity to community issues.

Overall, students enjoyed the course. Students noted that they learned a lot in the course and that it was “professionally run” and a “fantastic course.” 
Students also enjoyed Professor Myers’ “unbelievable teaching style.” 
However, students expressed frustration with the ambiguity in class grading and with the peer performance review, which seemed to engender a competitive class atmosphere. Students also acknowledged that the course “requires a lot of work and time throughout the semester.” Finally, several upperclassmen in the class noted that they would not recommend the class to upperclassmen, as it seemed largely geared toward underclassmen.
